fields.name: session_variables.auto_increment_increment
fields.description: auto_increment_increment and auto_increment_offset are intended for use with master-to-master replication, and can be used to control the operation of AUTO_INCREMENT columns. Both variables have global and session values, and each can assume an integer value between 1 and 65,535 inclusive. Setting the value of either of these two variables to 0 causes its value to be set to 1 instead. Attempting to set the value of either of these two variables to an integer greater than 65,535 or less than 0 causes its value to be set to 65,535 instead. Attempting to set the value of auto_increment_increment or auto_increment_offset to a noninteger value produces an error, and the actual value of the variable remains unchanged.

fields.name: session_variables.auto_increment_offset
fields.description: This variable has a default value of 1. For more information, see the description for auto_increment_increment.

fields.name: session_variables.autocommit
fields.description: The autocommit mode. If set to 1, all changes to a table take effect immediately. If set to 0, you must use COMMIT to accept a transaction or ROLLBACK to cancel it. If autocommit is 0 and you change it to 1, MySQL performs an automatic COMMIT of any open transaction. Another way to begin a transaction is to use a START TRANSACTION or BEGIN statement. See Section 13.3.1, 201cSTART TRANSACTION, COMMIT, and ROLLBACK Syntax”.

fields.name: session_variables.automatic_sp_privileges
fields.description: When this variable has a value of 1 (the default), the server automatically grants the EXECUTE and ALTER ROUTINE privileges to the creator of a stored routine, if the user cannot already execute and alter or drop the routine. (The ALTER ROUTINE privilege is required to drop the routine.) The server also automatically drops those privileges from the creator when the routine is dropped. If automatic_sp_privileges is 0, the server does not automatically add or drop these privileges.

fields.name: session_variables.avoid_temporal_upgrade
fields.description: This variable controls whether ALTER TABLE implicitly upgrades temporal columns found to be in pre-5.6.4 format (TIME, DATETIME, and TIMESTAMP columns without support for fractional seconds precision). Upgrading such columns requires a table rebuild, which prevents any use of fast alterations that might otherwise apply to the operation to be performed.

fields.name: session_variables.back_log
fields.description: The number of outstanding connection requests MySQL can have. This comes into play when the main MySQL thread gets very many connection requests in a very short time. It then takes some time (although very little) for the main thread to check the connection and start a new thread. The back_log value indicates how many requests can be stacked during this short time before MySQL momentarily stops answering new requests. You need to increase this only if you expect a large number of connections in a short period of time.

fields.name: session_variables.basedir
fields.description: The path to the MySQL installation base directory.

fields.name: session_variables.big_tables
fields.description: If set to 1, all temporary tables are stored on disk rather than in memory. This is a little slower, but the error The table tbl_name is full does not occur for SELECT operations that require a large temporary table. The default value for a new connection is 0 (use in-memory temporary tables). Normally, you should never need to set this variable, because in-memory tables are automatically converted to disk-based tables as required.

fields.name: session_variables.bind_address
fields.description: The value of the --bind-address option.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_cache_size
fields.description: The size of the cache to hold changes to the binary log during a transaction. A binary log cache is allocated for each client if the server supports any transactional storage engines and if the server has the binary log enabled (--log-bin option). If you often use large transactions, you can increase this cache size to get better performance. The Binlog_cache_use and Binlog_cache_disk_use status variables can be useful for tuning the size of this variable. See Section 5.4.4, “The Binary Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_checksum
fields.description: When enabled, this variable causes the master to write a checksum for each event in the binary log. binlog_checksum supports the values NONE (disabled) and CRC32. The default is CRC32 as of MySQL 5.6.6, NONE before that.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_direct_non_transactional_updates
fields.description: Due to concurrency issues, a slave can become inconsistent when a transaction contains updates to both transactional and nontransactional tables. MySQL tries to preserve causality among these statements by writing nontransactional statements to the transaction cache, which is flushed upon commit. However, problems arise when modifications done to nontransactional tables on behalf of a transaction become immediately visible to other connections because these changes may not be written immediately into the binary log.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_error_action
fields.description: Controls what happens when the server cannot write to the binary log, which can cause the master's log to become inconsistent and replication slaves to lose synchronization. Previous releases used the name binlogging_impossible_mode.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_format
fields.description: This variable sets the binary logging format, and can be any one of STATEMENT, ROW, or MIXED. See Section 17.1.2, “Replication Formats”. binlog_format is set by the --binlog-format option at startup, or by the binlog_format variable at runtime.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_gtid_simple_recovery
fields.description: This variable controls how binary log files are iterated during the search for GTIDs when MySQL starts or restarts. In MySQL version 5.6.21, this variable was added as simplified_binlog_gtid_recovery and in MySQL version 5.6.23 it was renamed to binlog_gtid_simple_recovery.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_order_commits
fields.description: If this variable is enabled (the default), transactions are committed in the same order they are written to the binary log. If disabled, transactions may be committed in parallel. In some cases, disabling this variable might produce a performance increment.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_row_image
fields.description: For MySQL row-based replication, this variable determines how row images are written to the binary log.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_rows_query_log_events
fields.description: The binlog_rows_query_log_events system variable affects row-based logging only. When enabled, it causes a MySQL 5.6.2 or later server to write informational log events such as row query log events into its binary log. This information can be used for debugging and related purposes; such as obtaining the original query issued on the master when it cannot be reconstructed from the row updates.

fields.name: session_variables.binlog_stmt_cache_size
fields.description: This variable determines the size of the cache for the binary log to hold nontransactional statements issued during a transaction. Separate binary log transaction and statement caches are allocated for each client if the server supports any transactional storage engines and if the server has the binary log enabled (--log-bin option). If you often use large nontransactional statements during transactions, you can increase this cache size to get better performance. The Binlog_stmt_cache_use and Binlog_stmt_cache_disk_use status variables can be useful for tuning the size of this variable. See Section 5.4.4, “The Binary Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.block_encryption_mode
fields.description: This variable controls the block encryption mode for block-based algorithms such as AES. It affects encryption for AES_ENCRYPT() and AES_DECRYPT().

fields.name: session_variables.bulk_insert_buffer_size
fields.description: MyISAM uses a special tree-like cache to make bulk inserts faster for INSERT ... SELECT, INSERT ... VALUES (...), (...), ..., and LOAD DATA INFILE when adding data to nonempty tables. This variable limits the size of the cache tree in bytes per thread. Setting it to 0 disables this optimization. The default value is 8MB.

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_client
fields.description: The character set for statements that arrive from the client. The session value of this variable is set using the character set requested by the client when the client connects to the server. (Many clients support a --default-character-set option to enable this character set to be specified explicitly. See also Section 10.1.4, “Connection Character Sets and Collations”.) The global value of the variable is used to set the session value in cases when the client-requested value is unknown or not available, or the server is configured to ignore client requests:

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_connection
fields.description: The character set used for literals that do not have a character set introducer and for number-to-string conversion. For information about introducers, see Section 10.1.3.8, “Character Set Introducers”.

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_database
fields.description: The character set used by the default database. The server sets this variable whenever the default database changes. If there is no default database, the variable has the same value as character_set_server.

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_filesystem
fields.description: The file system character set. This variable is used to interpret string literals that refer to file names, such as in the LOAD DATA INFILE and SELECT ... INTO OUTFILE statements and the LOAD_FILE() function. Such file names are converted from character_set_client to character_set_filesystem before the file opening attempt occurs. The default value is binary, which means that no conversion occurs. For systems on which multibyte file names are permitted, a different value may be more appropriate. For example, if the system represents file names using UTF-8, set character_set_filesystem to 'utf8'.

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_results
fields.description: The character set used for returning query results such as result sets or error messages to the client.

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_server
fields.description: The server's default character set.

fields.name: session_variables.character_set_system
fields.description: The character set used by the server for storing identifiers. The value is always utf8.

fields.name: session_variables.character_sets_dir
fields.description: The directory where character sets are installed.

fields.name: session_variables.collation_connection
fields.description: The collation of the connection character set.

fields.name: session_variables.collation_database
fields.description: The collation used by the default database. The server sets this variable whenever the default database changes. If there is no default database, the variable has the same value as collation_server.

fields.name: session_variables.collation_server
fields.description: The server's default collation.

fields.name: session_variables.completion_type
fields.description: The transaction completion type. This variable can take the values shown in the following table. The variable can be assigned using either the name values or corresponding integer values.

fields.name: session_variables.concurrent_insert
fields.description: If AUTO (the default), MySQL permits INSERT and SELECT statements to run concurrently for MyISAM tables that have no free blocks in the middle of the data file. If you start mysqld with --skip-new, this variable is set to NEVER.

fields.name: session_variables.connect_timeout
fields.description: The number of seconds that the mysqld server waits for a connect packet before responding with Bad handshake. The default value is 10 seconds.

fields.name: session_variables.core_file
fields.description: Whether to write a core file if the server crashes. This variable is set by the --core-file option.

fields.name: session_variables.datadir
fields.description: The path to the MySQL server data directory. Relative paths are resolved with respect to the current directory. If the server will be started automatically (that is, in contexts for which you cannot assume what the current directory will be), it is best to specify the datadir value as an absolute path.

fields.name: session_variables.date_format
fields.description: This variable is unused. It is deprecated and will be removed in a future MySQL release.

fields.name: session_variables.datetime_format
fields.description: This variable is unused. It is deprecated and will be removed in a future MySQL release.

fields.name: session_variables.default_storage_engine
fields.description: The default storage engine. This variable sets the storage engine for permanent tables only. To set the storage engine for TEMPORARY tables, set the default_tmp_storage_engine system variable.

fields.name: session_variables.default_tmp_storage_engine
fields.description: The default storage engine for TEMPORARY tables (created with CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE). To set the storage engine for permanent tables, set the default_storage_engine system variable.

fields.name: session_variables.default_week_format
fields.description: The default mode value to use for the WEEK() function. See Section 12.7, “Date and Time Functions”.

fields.name: session_variables.delay_key_write
fields.description: This option applies only to MyISAM tables. It can have one of the following values to affect handling of the DELAY_KEY_WRITE table option that can be used in CREATE TABLE statements.

fields.name: session_variables.delayed_insert_limit
fields.description: After inserting delayed_insert_limit delayed rows into a nontransactional table, the INSERT DELAYED handler thread checks whether there are any SELECT statements pending. If so, it permits them to execute before continuing to insert delayed rows.

fields.name: session_variables.delayed_insert_timeout
fields.description: How many seconds an INSERT DELAYED handler thread should wait for INSERT statements before terminating.

fields.name: session_variables.delayed_queue_size
fields.description: This is a per-table limit on the number of rows to queue when handling INSERT DELAYED statements for nontransactional tables. If the queue becomes full, any client that issues an INSERT DELAYED statement waits until there is room in the queue again.

fields.name: session_variables.disconnect_on_expired_password
fields.description: This variable controls how the server handles clients with expired passwords:

fields.name: session_variables.div_precision_increment
fields.description: This variable indicates the number of digits by which to increase the scale of the result of division operations performed with the / operator. The default value is 4. The minimum and maximum values are 0 and 30, respectively. The following example illustrates the effect of increasing the default value.

fields.name: session_variables.end_markers_in_json
fields.description: Whether optimizer JSON output should add end markers. See MySQL Internals: The end_markers_in_json System Variable.

fields.name: session_variables.enforce_gtid_consistency
fields.description: When enabled, this option enforces GTID consistency by allowing execution of only those statements that can be logged in a transactionally safe manner. You must enable --enforce-gtid-consistency before setting --gtid-mode to ON; otherwise, enabling GTID mode fails with an error. You can (and should) use this option prior to using --gtid-mode, in order to test whether the system is ready to use GTIDs.

fields.name: session_variables.eq_range_index_dive_limit
fields.description: This variable indicates the number of equality ranges in an equality comparison condition when the optimizer should switch from using index dives to index statistics in estimating the number of qualifying rows. It applies to evaluation of expressions that have either of these equivalent forms, where the optimizer uses a nonunique index to look up col_name values:

fields.name: session_variables.error_count
fields.description: The number of errors that resulted from the last statement that generated messages.

fields.name: session_variables.event_scheduler
fields.description: This variable indicates the status of the Event Scheduler; possible values are ON, OFF, and DISABLED, with the default being OFF. This variable and its effects on the Event Scheduler's operation are discussed in greater detail in the Overview section of the Events chapter.

fields.name: session_variables.expire_logs_days
fields.description: The number of days for automatic binary log file removal. The default is 0, which means “no automatic removal.” Possible removals happen at startup and when the binary log is flushed. Log flushing occurs as indicated in Section 5.4, “MySQL Server Logs”.

fields.name: session_variables.explicit_defaults_for_timestamp
fields.description: This system variable determines whether the server enables certain nonstandard behaviors for default values and NULL-value handling in TIMESTAMP columns. By default, explicit_defaults_for_timestamp is disabled, which enables the nonstandard behaviors.

fields.name: session_variables.external_user
fields.description: The external user name used during the authentication process, as set by the plugin used to authenticate the client. With native (built-in) MySQL authentication, or if the plugin does not set the value, this variable is NULL. See Section 6.3.8, “Proxy Users”.

fields.name: session_variables.flush
fields.description: If ON, the server flushes (synchronizes) all changes to disk after each SQL statement. Normally, MySQL does a write of all changes to disk only after each SQL statement and lets the operating system handle the synchronizing to disk. See Section B.5.3.3, “What to Do If MySQL Keeps Crashing”. This variable is set to ON if you start mysqld with the --flush option.

fields.name: session_variables.flush_time
fields.description: If this is set to a nonzero value, all tables are closed every flush_time seconds to free up resources and synchronize unflushed data to disk. This option is best used only on systems with minimal resources. The default is 0.

fields.name: session_variables.foreign_key_checks
fields.description: If set to 1 (the default), foreign key constraints for InnoDB tables are checked. If set to 0, foreign key constraints are ignored, with a couple of exceptions. When re-creating a table that was dropped, an error is returned if the table definition does not conform to the foreign key constraints referencing the table. Likewise, an ALTER TABLE operation returns an error if a foreign key definition is incorrectly formed. For more information, see Section 13.1.17.6, “Using FOREIGN KEY Constraints”.

fields.name: session_variables.ft_boolean_syntax
fields.description: The list of operators supported by boolean full-text searches performed using IN BOOLEAN MODE. See Section 12.9.2, “Boolean Full-Text Searches”.

fields.name: session_variables.ft_max_word_len
fields.description: The maximum length of the word to be included in a MyISAM FULLTEXT index.

fields.name: session_variables.ft_min_word_len
fields.description: The minimum length of the word to be included in a MyISAM FULLTEXT index.

fields.name: session_variables.ft_query_expansion_limit
fields.description: The number of top matches to use for full-text searches performed using WITH QUERY EXPANSION.

fields.name: session_variables.ft_stopword_file
fields.description: The file from which to read the list of stopwords for full-text searches on MyISAM tables. The server looks for the file in the data directory unless an absolute path name is given to specify a different directory. All the words from the file are used; comments are not honored. By default, a built-in list of stopwords is used (as defined in the storage/myisam/ft_static.c file). Setting this variable to the empty string ('') disables stopword filtering. See also Section 12.9.4, “Full-Text Stopwords”.

fields.name: session_variables.general_log
fields.description: Whether the general query log is enabled. The value can be 0 (or OFF) to disable the log or 1 (or ON) to enable the log. The default value depends on whether the --general_log option is given. The destination for log output is controlled by the log_output system variable; if that value is NONE, no log entries are written even if the log is enabled.

fields.name: session_variables.general_log_file
fields.description: The name of the general query log file. The default value is host_name.log, but the initial value can be changed with the --general_log_file option.

fields.name: session_variables.group_concat_max_len
fields.description: The maximum permitted result length in bytes for the GROUP_CONCAT() function. The default is 1024.

fields.name: session_variables.gtid_mode
fields.description: This option specifies whether global transaction identifiers (GTIDs) are used to identify transactions. Starting the server with --gtid-mode=ON requires that the server also be started with the --log-bin, --log-slave-updates, and --enforce-gtid-consistency options.

fields.name: session_variables.gtid_next
fields.description: This variable is used to specify whether and how the next GTID is obtained. gtid_next can take any of the following values:

fields.name: session_variables.gtid_owned
fields.description: This read-only variable holds a list whose contents depend on its scope. When used with session scope, the list holds all GTIDs that are owned by this client; when used with global scope, it holds a list of all GTIDs along with their owners.

fields.name: session_variables.gtid_purged
fields.description: The set of all transactions that have been purged from the binary log. This is a subset of the set of transactions in gtid_executed.

fields.name: session_variables.have_compress
fields.description: YES if the zlib compression library is available to the server, NO if not. If not, the COMPRESS() and UNCOMPRESS() functions cannot be used.

fields.name: session_variables.have_crypt
fields.description: YES if the crypt() system call is available to the server, NO if not. If not, the ENCRYPT() function cannot be used.

fields.name: session_variables.have_dynamic_loading
fields.description: YES if mysqld supports dynamic loading of plugins, NO if not. If the value is NO, you cannot use options such as --plugin-load to load plugins at server startup, or the INSTALL PLUGIN statement to load plugins at runtime.

fields.name: session_variables.have_geometry
fields.description: YES if the server supports spatial data types, NO if not.

fields.name: session_variables.have_openssl
fields.description: YES if mysqld supports SSL connections, NO if not. DISABLED indicates that the server was compiled with SSL support, but was not started with the appropriate --ssl-xxx options.

fields.name: session_variables.have_profiling
fields.description: YES if statement profiling capability is present, NO if not. If present, the profiling system variable controls whether this capability is enabled or disabled. This variable is deprecated and will be removed in a future MySQL release.

fields.name: session_variables.have_query_cache
fields.description: YES if mysqld supports the query cache, NO if not.

fields.name: session_variables.have_rtree_keys
fields.description: YES if RTREE indexes are available, NO if not. (These are used for spatial indexes in MyISAM tables.)

fields.name: session_variables.have_ssl
fields.description: YES if mysqld supports SSL connections, NO if not. DISABLED indicates that the server was compiled with SSL support, but was not started with the appropriate --ssl-xxx options. For more information, see Section 6.4.5, “Building MySQL with Support for Encrypted Connections”.

fields.name: session_variables.have_symlink
fields.description: YES if symbolic link support is enabled, NO if not. This is required on Unix for support of the DATA DIRECTORY and INDEX DIRECTORY table options, and on Windows for support of data directory symlinks. If the server is started with the --skip-symbolic-links option, the value is DISABLED.

fields.name: session_variables.host_cache_size
fields.description: The size of the internal host cache (see Section 8.12.5.2, “DNS Lookup Optimization and the Host Cache”). Setting the size to 0 disables the host cache. Changing the cache size at runtime implicitly causes a FLUSH HOSTS operation to clear the host cache and truncate the host_cache table.

fields.name: session_variables.hostname
fields.description: The server sets this variable to the server host name at startup.

fields.name: session_variables.identity
fields.description: This variable is a synonym for the last_insert_id variable. It exists for compatibility with other database systems. You can read its value with SELECT @@identity, and set it using SET identity.

fields.name: session_variables.ignore_builtin_innodb
fields.description: In MySQL 5.6, InnoDB is the default storage engine and InnoDB Plugin is not used, so

fields.name: session_variables.ignore_db_dirs
fields.description: A comma-separated list of names that are not considered as database directories in the data directory. The value is set from any instances of --ignore-db-dir given at server startup.

fields.name: session_variables.init_connect
fields.description: A string to be executed by the server for each client that connects. The string consists of one or more SQL statements, separated by semicolon characters. For example, each client session begins by default with autocommit mode enabled. For older servers (before MySQL 5.5.8), there is no global autocommit system variable to specify that autocommit should be disabled by default, but as a workaround init_connect can be used to achieve the same effect:

fields.name: session_variables.init_file
fields.description: The name of the file specified with the --init-file option when you start the server. This should be a file containing SQL statements that you want the server to execute when it starts. Each statement must be on a single line and should not include comments. For more information, see the description of --init-file.

fields.name: session_variables.init_slave
fields.description: This variable is similar to init_connect, but is a string to be executed by a slave server each time the SQL thread starts. The format of the string is the same as for the init_connect variable.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_adaptive_flushing
fields.description: Specifies whether to dynamically adjust the rate of flushing dirty pages in the InnoDB buffer pool based on the workload. Adjusting the flush rate dynamically is intended to avoid bursts of I/O activity.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_adaptive_flushing_lwm
fields.description: Defines the low water mark representing percentage of redo log capacity at which adaptive flushing is enabled.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_adaptive_hash_index
fields.description: Whether innodb adaptive hash indexes are enabled or disabled.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_adaptive_hash_index_parts
fields.description: Partitions the adaptive hash index search system. Each index is bound to a specific partition, with each partition protected by a separate latch.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_adaptive_max_sleep_delay
fields.description: Permits InnoDB to automatically adjust the value of innodb_thread_sleep_delay up or down according to the current workload.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_aggressive_pc
fields.description: Enable aggressive innodb page cleaners.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_autoextend_increment
fields.description: The increment size (in megabytes) for extending the size of an auto-extending InnoDB system tablespace file when it becomes full.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_autoinc_lock_mode
fields.description: The lock mode to use for generating auto-increment values.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_buffer_pool_dump_pct
fields.description: Specifies the percentage of the most recently used pages for each buffer pool to read out and dump.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_buffer_pool_size
fields.description: The size in bytes of the buffer pool, the memory area where InnoDB caches table and index data.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_change_buffer_max_size
fields.description: Maximum size for the InnoDB change buffer, as a percentage of the total size of the buffer pool. You might increase this value for a MySQL server with heavy insert, update, and delete activity, or decrease it for a MySQL server with unchanging data used for reporting.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_change_buffering
fields.description: Whether InnoDB performs change buffering, an optimization that delays write operations to secondary indexes so that the I/O operations can be performed sequentially.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_checksum_algorithm
fields.description: Specifies how to generate and verify the checksum stored in the disk blocks of InnoDB tablespaces.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_chunk_write_enabled
fields.description: Split the write requests larger than 128KB into small chunks to reduce I/O latency

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_cmp_per_index_enabled
fields.description: Enables per-index compression-related statistics in the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.INNODB_CMP_PER_INDEX table. Because these statistics can be expensive to gather, only enable this option on development, test, or slave instances during performance tuning related to InnoDB compressed tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_commit_concurrency
fields.description: The number of threads that can commit at the same time. A value of 0 (the default) permits any number of transactions to commit simultaneously. The value of innodb_commit_concurrency cannot be changed at runtime from zero to nonzero or vice versa. The value can be changed from one nonzero value to another.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_compression_failure_threshold_pct
fields.description: Defines the compression failure rate threshold for a table, as a percentage, at which point MySQL begins adding padding within compressed pages to avoid expensive compression failures.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_compression_level
fields.description: Specifies the level of zlib compression to use for InnoDB compressed tables and indexes. A higher value lets you fit more data onto a storage device, at the expense of more CPU overhead during compression. A lower value lets you reduce CPU overhead when storage space is not critical, or you expect the data is not especially compressible.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_compression_pad_pct_max
fields.description: Specifies the maximum percentage that can be reserved as free space within each compressed page, allowing room to reorganize the data and modification log within the page when a compressed table or index is updated and the data might be recompressed. Only applies when innodb_compression_failure_threshold_pct is set to a nonzero value, and the rate of compression failures passes the cutoff point.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_concurrency_tickets
fields.description: Determines the number of threads that can enter InnoDB concurrently.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_deadlock_detect
fields.description: This option is used to disable deadlock detection. On high concurrency systems, deadlock detection can cause a slowdown when numerous threads wait for the same lock.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_default_row_format
fields.description: The innodb_default_row_format option defines the default row format for InnoDB tables and user-created temporary tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_delay_datasync
fields.description: Delay innodb data pages synchronization and flush util all batches are done.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_delay_logwrite
fields.description: Delay innodb log write until all data pages batches are done.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_disable_sort_file_cache
fields.description: Disables the operating system file system cache for merge-sort temporary files. The effect is to open such files with the equivalent of O_DIRECT.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_disk_buffer_pool_filename
fields.description: File name of MySQL BPE file

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_disk_buffer_pool_size
fields.description: Size of MySQL BPE in byte

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_doublewrite
fields.description: When enabled, InnoDB stores all data twice, first to the doublewrite buffer, then to the actual data files.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_fast0ext_enabled
fields.description: Use fast method to expand the data file

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_fast_init_buffer_pool
fields.description: Fast init buffer pool.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_fast_shutdown
fields.description: The InnoDB shutdown mode. If the value is 0, InnoDB does a slow shutdown, a full purge and a change buffer merge before shutting down. If the value is 1 (the default), InnoDB skips these operations at shutdown, a process known as a fast shutdown. If the value is 2, InnoDB flushes its logs and shuts down cold, as if MySQL had crashed; no committed transactions are lost, but the crash recovery operation makes the next startup take longer.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_fatal_semaphore_wait_threshold
fields.description: The seconds of mysql engine waiting for I/O, this threshold timeout will result in mysql engine crash.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_file_format
fields.description: Indicates the InnoDB file format for file-per-table tablespaces.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_file_per_table
fields.description: session_variables.innodb stores the data and indexes for each newly created table in a separate .ibd file instead of the system tablespace. It cannot be updated any more for a master/replica server to keep the replication consistency.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_fill_factor
fields.description: session_variables.innodb performs a bulk load when creating or rebuilding indexes.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit
fields.description: Controls the balance between strict ACID compliance for commit operations and higher performance that is possible when commit-related I/O operations are rearranged and done in batches.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_flush_method
fields.description: Defines the method used to flush data to InnoDB data files and log files, which can affect I/O throughput.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_flush_neighbors
fields.description: Specifies whether flushing a page from the InnoDB buffer pool also flushes other dirty pages in the same extent.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_flush_sync
fields.description: Causes the innodb_io_capacity setting to be ignored for bursts of I/O activity that occur at checkpoints.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_flushing_avg_loops
fields.description: Number of iterations for which InnoDB keeps the previously calculated snapshot of the flushing state, controlling how quickly adaptive flushing responds to changing workloads.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_force_load_corrupted
fields.description: Permits InnoDB to load tables at startup that are marked as corrupted. Use only during troubleshooting, to recover data that is otherwise inaccessible.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_force_recovery
fields.description: The crash recovery mode, typically only changed in serious troubleshooting situations.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_cache_size
fields.description: The memory allocated, in bytes, for the InnoDB FULLTEXT search index cache, which holds a parsed document in memory while creating an InnoDB FULLTEXT index.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_enable_diag_print
fields.description: Whether to enable additional full-text search (FTS) diagnostic output. This option is primarily intended for advanced FTS debugging and will not be of interest to most users. Output is printed to the error log.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_enable_stopword
fields.description: Specifies that a set of stopwords is associated with an InnoDB FULLTEXT index at the time the index is created.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_max_token_size
fields.description: Maximum character length of words that are stored in an InnoDB FULLTEXT index.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_min_token_size
fields.description: Minimum length of words that are stored in an InnoDB FULLTEXT index.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_num_word_optimize
fields.description: Number of words to process during each OPTIMIZE TABLE operation on an InnoDB FULLTEXT index.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_result_cache_limit
fields.description: The InnoDB full-text search query result cache limit (defined in bytes) per full-text search query or per thread.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_server_stopword_table
fields.description: This option is used to specify your own InnoDB FULLTEXT index stopword list for all InnoDB tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_sort_pll_degree
fields.description: Number of threads used in parallel to index and tokenize text in an InnoDB FULLTEXT index when building a search index.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_total_cache_size
fields.description: The total memory allocated, in bytes, for the InnoDB full-text search index cache for all tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_ft_user_stopword_table
fields.description: This option is used to specify your own InnoDB FULLTEXT index stopword list on a specific table.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_io_capacity
fields.description: Sets an upper limit on I/O activity performed by InnoDB background tasks, such as flushing pages from the buffer pool and merging data from the change buffer.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_io_capacity_max
fields.description: If flushing activity falls behind, InnoDB can flush more aggressively than the limit imposed by innodb_io_capacity. innodb_io_capacity_max defines an upper limit the number of I/O operations performed per second by InnoDB background tasks in such situations.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_keybsize_min
fields.description: Minimum supported KEY_BLOCK_SIZE.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_large_prefix
fields.description: When this option is enabled, index key prefixes longer than 767 bytes (up to 3072 bytes) are allowed for InnoDB tables that use DYNAMIC or COMPRESSED row format.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_lock_wait_timeout
fields.description: The length of time in seconds an InnoDB transaction waits for a row lock before giving up.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_log_buffer_size
fields.description: The size in bytes of the buffer that InnoDB uses to write to the log files on disk.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_log_checksums
fields.description: Enables or disables checksums for redo log pages.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_log_compressed_pages
fields.description: Specifies whether images of re-compressed pages are written to the redo log.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_log_flush_shallow_check
fields.description: Do an LSN shallow check before flushing innodb log.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_log_wrlock_retrymax
fields.description: Number of retries for the log write lock.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_lru_scan_depth
fields.description: A parameter that influences the algorithms and heuristics for the flush operation for the InnoDB buffer pool.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_max_dirty_pages_pct
fields.description: session_variables.innodb tries to flush data from the buffer pool so that the percentage of dirty pages does not exceed this value.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_max_dirty_pages_pct_lwm
fields.description: Defines a low water mark representing the percentage of dirty pages at which preflushing is enabled to control the dirty page ratio.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_max_purge_lag
fields.description: Defines the maximum length of the purge queue. The default value of 0 indicates no limit (no delays).

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_max_purge_lag_delay
fields.description: Specifies the maximum delay in microseconds for the delay imposed by the innodb_max_purge_lag configuration option.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_max_undo_log_size
fields.description: Defines a threshold size for undo tablespaces.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_monitor_disable
fields.description: Disables InnoDB metrics counters. Counter data may be queried using the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.INNODB_METRICS table.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_monitor_enable
fields.description: Enables InnoDB metrics counters.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_monitor_reset
fields.description: Resets the count value for InnoDB metrics counters to zero.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_monitor_reset_all
fields.description: Resets all values (minimum, maximum, and so on) for InnoDB metrics counters.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_old_blocks_pct
fields.description: Specifies the approximate percentage of the InnoDB buffer pool used for the old block sublist.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_old_blocks_time
fields.description: Non-zero values protect against the buffer pool being filled by data that is referenced only for a brief period, such as during a full table scan.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_online_alter_log_max_size
fields.description: Specifies an upper limit on the size of the temporary log files used during online DDL operations for InnoDB tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_open_files
fields.description: This configuration option is only relevant if you use multiple InnoDB tablespaces. It specifies the maximum number of .ibd files that MySQL can keep open at one time.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_optimize_fulltext_only
fields.description: Changes the way OPTIMIZE TABLE operates on InnoDB tables. Intended to be enabled temporarily, during maintenance operations for InnoDB tables with FULLTEXT indexes.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_page_cleaners
fields.description: The number of page cleaner threads that flush dirty pages from buffer pool instances.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_print_all_deadlocks
fields.description: When this option is enabled, information about all deadlocks in InnoDB user transactions is recorded in the mysqld error log.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_purge_batch_size
fields.description: Defines the number of undo log pages that purge parses and processes in one batch from the history list.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_purge_rseg_truncate_frequency
fields.description: Defines the frequency with which the purge system frees rollback segments in terms of the number of times that purge is invoked. Reducing this value increases the frequency with which the purge thread frees rollback segments.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_purge_threads
fields.description: The number of background threads devoted to the InnoDB purge operation.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_random_read_ahead
fields.description: Enables the random read-ahead technique for optimizing InnoDB I/O.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_read_ahead_threshold
fields.description: Controls the sensitivity of linear read-ahead that InnoDB uses to prefetch pages into the buffer pool.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_read_io_threads
fields.description: The number of I/O threads for read operations in InnoDB.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_read_only
fields.description: Starts InnoDB in read-only mode.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_replication_delay
fields.description: The replication thread delay in milliseconds on a slave server if innodb_thread_concurrency is reached.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_rollback_on_timeout
fields.description: session_variables.innodb rolls back only the last statement on a transaction timeout by default. If --innodb_rollback_on_timeout is specified, a transaction timeout causes InnoDB to abort and roll back the entire transaction.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_rollback_segments
fields.description: Defines the number of rollback segments used by InnoDB.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_shutdown_clean_memory
fields.description: Clean innodb related object on shutdown.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_spin_wait_delay
fields.description: The maximum delay between polls for a spin lock.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_auto_recalc
fields.description: Causes InnoDB to automatically recalculate persistent statistics after the data in a table is changed substantially.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_include_delete_marked
fields.description: Enabled to ensure that InnoDB includes delete-marked records when calculating persistent optimizer statistics.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_method
fields.description: How the server treats NULL values when collecting statistics about the distribution of index values for InnoDB tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_on_metadata
fields.description: This option only applies when optimizer statistics are configured to be non-persistent. When innodb_stats_on_metadata is enabled, InnoDB updates non-persistent statistics when metadata statements such as SHOW TABLE STATUS or when accessing the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES or INFORMATION_SCHEMA.STATISTICS tables.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_persistent
fields.description: Specifies whether InnoDB index statistics are persisted to disk. Otherwise, statistics may be recalculated frequently which can lead to variations in query execution plans.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_persistent_sample_pages
fields.description: The number of index pages to sample when estimating cardinality and other statistics for an indexed column, such as those calculated by ANALYZE TABLE.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_stats_transient_sample_pages
fields.description: The number of index pages to sample when estimating cardinality and other statistics for an indexed column, such as those calculated by ANALYZE TABLE.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_status_output
fields.description: Enables or disables periodic output for the standard InnoDB Monitor.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_status_output_locks
fields.description: Enables or disables the InnoDB Lock Monitor.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_strict_mode
fields.description: When innodb_strict_mode is enabled, InnoDB returns errors rather than warnings for certain conditions.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_sync_array_size
fields.description: Defines the size of the mutex/lock wait array. Increasing the value splits the internal data structure used to coordinate threads, for higher concurrency in workloads with large numbers of waiting threads.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_sync_spin_loops
fields.description: The number of times a thread waits for an InnoDB mutex to be freed before the thread is suspended.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_table_locks
fields.description: The default value of innodb_table_locks is 1, which means that LOCK TABLES causes InnoDB to lock a table internally if autocommit = 0.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_temp_data_file_path
fields.description: Specifies the path, file name, and file size for InnoDB temporary tablespace data files.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_thread_concurrency
fields.description: session_variables.innodb tries to keep the number of operating system threads concurrently inside InnoDB less than or equal to the limit given by this variable.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_thread_sleep_delay
fields.description: Defines how long InnoDB threads sleep before joining the InnoDB queue, in microseconds.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_tmpdir
fields.description: Used to define an alternate directory for temporary sort files created during online ALTER TABLE operations that rebuild the table.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_undo_log_truncate
fields.description: When enabled, undo tablespaces that exceed the threshold value defined by innodb_max_undo_log_size are marked for truncation.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_undolog_init_mt
fields.description: Use multi-thread undo log list initialize or not.

fields.name: session_variables.innodb_write_io_threads
fields.description: The number of I/O threads for write operations in InnoDB.

fields.name: session_variables.insert_id
fields.description: The value to be used by the following INSERT or ALTER TABLE statement when inserting an AUTO_INCREMENT value. This is mainly used with the binary log.

fields.name: session_variables.interactive_timeout
fields.description: The number of seconds the server waits for activity on an interactive connection before closing it. An interactive client is defined as a client that uses the CLIENT_INTERACTIVE option to mysql_real_connect(). See also wait_timeout.

fields.name: session_variables.join_buffer_size
fields.description: The minimum size of the buffer that is used for plain index scans, range index scans, and joins that do not use indexes and thus perform full table scans. Normally, the best way to get fast joins is to add indexes. Increase the value of join_buffer_size to get a faster full join when adding indexes is not possible. One join buffer is allocated for each full join between two tables. For a complex join between several tables for which indexes are not used, multiple join buffers might be necessary.

fields.name: session_variables.keep_files_on_create
fields.description: If a MyISAM table is created with no DATA DIRECTORY option, the .MYD file is created in the database directory. By default, if MyISAM finds an existing .MYD file in this case, it overwrites it. The same applies to .MYI files for tables created with no INDEX DIRECTORY option. To suppress this behavior, set the keep_files_on_create variable to ON (1), in which case MyISAM will not overwrite existing files and returns an error instead. The default value is OFF (0).

fields.name: session_variables.key_buffer_size
fields.description: Index blocks for MyISAM tables are buffered and are shared by all threads. key_buffer_size is the size of the buffer used for index blocks. The key buffer is also known as the key cache.

fields.name: session_variables.key_cache_age_threshold
fields.description: This value controls the demotion of buffers from the hot sublist of a key cache to the warm sublist. Lower values cause demotion to happen more quickly. The minimum value is 100. The default value is 300. See Section 8.10.2, “The MyISAM Key Cache”.

fields.name: session_variables.key_cache_block_size
fields.description: The size in bytes of blocks in the key cache. The default value is 1024. See Section 8.10.2, “The MyISAM Key Cache”.

fields.name: session_variables.key_cache_division_limit
fields.description: The division point between the hot and warm sublists of the key cache buffer list. The value is the percentage of the buffer list to use for the warm sublist. Permissible values range from 1 to 100. The default value is 100. See Section 8.10.2, “The MyISAM Key Cache”.

fields.name: session_variables.large_files_support
fields.description: Whether mysqld was compiled with options for large file support.

fields.name: session_variables.large_page_size
fields.description: If large page support is enabled, this shows the size of memory pages. Large memory pages are supported only on Linux; on other platforms, the value of this variable is always 0. See Section 8.12.4.2, “Enabling Large Page Support”.

fields.name: session_variables.large_pages
fields.description: Whether large page support is enabled (via the --large-pages option). See Section 8.12.4.2, “Enabling Large Page Support”.

fields.name: session_variables.last_insert_id
fields.description: The value to be returned from LAST_INSERT_ID(). This is stored in the binary log when you use LAST_INSERT_ID() in a statement that updates a table. Setting this variable does not update the value returned by the mysql_insert_id() C API function.

fields.name: session_variables.lc_messages
fields.description: The locale to use for error messages. The default is en_US. The server converts the argument to a language name and combines it with the value of lc_messages_dir to produce the location for the error message file. See Section 10.2, “Setting the Error Message Language”.

fields.name: session_variables.lc_messages_dir
fields.description: The directory where error messages are located. The server uses the value together with the value of lc_messages to produce the location for the error message file. See Section 10.2, “Setting the Error Message Language”.

fields.name: session_variables.lc_time_names
fields.description: This variable specifies the locale that controls the language used to display day and month names and abbreviations. This variable affects the output from the DATE_FORMAT(), DAYNAME() and MONTHNAME() functions. Locale names are POSIX-style values such as 'ja_JP' or 'pt_BR'. The default value is 'en_US' regardless of your system's locale setting. For further information, see Section 10.7, “MySQL Server Locale Support”.

fields.name: session_variables.license
fields.description: The type of license the server has.

fields.name: session_variables.local_infile
fields.description: This variable controls server-side LOCAL capability for LOAD DATA statements. Depending on the local_infile setting, the server refuses or permits local data loading by clients that have LOCAL enabled on the client side.

fields.name: session_variables.lock_wait_timeout
fields.description: This variable specifies the timeout in seconds for attempts to acquire metadata locks. The permissible values range from 1 to 31536000 (1 year). The default is 31536000.

fields.name: session_variables.locked_in_memory
fields.description: Whether mysqld was locked in memory with --memlock.

fields.name: session_variables.log_bin
fields.description: Enable binary logging. The server logs all statements that change data to the binary log, which is used for backup and replication. See Section 5.4.4, “The Binary Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_bin_basename
fields.description: Holds the name and complete path to the binary log file. Unlike the log_bin system variable, log_bin_basename reflects the name set with the --log-bin server option.

fields.name: session_variables.log_bin_index
fields.description: The index file for binary log file names.

fields.name: session_variables.log_bin_trust_function_creators
fields.description: This variable applies when binary logging is enabled. It controls whether stored function creators can be trusted not to create stored functions that will cause unsafe events to be written to the binary log. If set to 0 (the default), users are not permitted to create or alter stored functions unless they have the SUPER privilege in addition to the CREATE ROUTINE or ALTER ROUTINE privilege. A setting of 0 also enforces the restriction that a function must be declared with the DETERMINISTIC characteristic, or with the READS SQL DATA or NO SQL characteristic. If the variable is set to 1, MySQL does not enforce these restrictions on stored function creation. This variable also applies to trigger creation. See Section 20.7, “Binary Logging of Stored Programs”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_bin_use_v1_row_events
fields.description: Version 2 binary log row events are available beginning with MySQL 5.6.6; however, Version 2 events cannot be read by previous MySQL Server releases. Setting this option to 1 causes mysqld to write the binary log using Version 1 logging events, which is the only version of binary log events used in previous releases, and thus produce binary logs that can be read by older slaves. Setting --log-bin-use-v1-row-events to 0 (the default) causes mysqld to use Version 2 binary log events.

fields.name: session_variables.log_error
fields.description: The name of the error log file, or empty if the server is writing error messages to the console rather than to a named file. See Section 5.4.2, “The Error Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_output
fields.description: The destination for general query log and slow query log output. The value can be a comma-separated list of one or more of the words TABLE (log to tables), FILE (log to files), or NONE (do not log to tables or files). The default value is FILE. NONE, if present, takes precedence over any other specifiers. If the value is NONE log entries are not written even if the logs are enabled. If the logs are not enabled, no logging occurs even if the value of log_output is not NONE. For more information, see Section 5.4.1, “Selecting General Query and Slow Query Log Output Destinations”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_queries_not_using_indexes
fields.description: Whether queries that do not use indexes are logged to the slow query log. See Section 5.4.5, “The Slow Query Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_slave_updates
fields.description: Whether updates received by a slave server from a master server should be logged to the slave's own binary log. Binary logging must be enabled on the slave for this variable to have any effect. See Section 17.1.4, “Replication and Binary Logging Options and Variables”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_slow_admin_statements
fields.description: Include slow administrative statements in the statements written to the slow query log. Administrative statements include ALTER TABLE, ANALYZE TABLE, CHECK TABLE, CREATE INDEX, DROP INDEX, OPTIMIZE TABLE, and REPAIR TABLE.

fields.name: session_variables.log_slow_slave_statements
fields.description: When the slow query log is enabled, this variable enables logging for queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds to execute on the slave. This variable was added in MySQL 5.6.11.

fields.name: session_variables.log_throttle_queries_not_using_indexes
fields.description: If log_queries_not_using_indexes is enabled, the log_throttle_queries_not_using_indexes variable limits the number of such queries per minute that can be written to the slow query log. A value of 0 (the default) means “no limit”. For more information, see Section 5.4.5, “The Slow Query Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.log_warnings
fields.description: Whether to produce additional warning messages to the error log. This variable is enabled by default with a value of 1. To disable it, set it to 0. If the value is greater than 0, the server logs messages about statements that are unsafe for statement-based logging. If the value is greater than 1, the server logs aborted connections and access-denied errors for new connection attempts. See Section B.5.2.11, “Communication Errors and Aborted Connections”.

fields.name: session_variables.long_query_time
fields.description: If a query takes longer than this many seconds, the server increments the Slow_queries status variable. If the slow query log is enabled, the query is logged to the slow query log file. This value is measured in real time, not CPU time, so a query that is under the threshold on a lightly loaded system might be above the threshold on a heavily loaded one. The minimum and default values of long_query_time are 0 and 10, respectively. The value can be specified to a resolution of microseconds. For logging to a file, times are written including the microseconds part. For logging to tables, only integer times are written; the microseconds part is ignored. See Section 5.4.5, “The Slow Query Log”.

fields.name: session_variables.low_priority_updates
fields.description: If set to 1, all INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, and LOCK TABLE WRITE statements wait until there is no pending SELECT or LOCK TABLE READ on the affected table. This affects only storage engines that use only table-level locking (such as MyISAM, MEMORY, and MERGE).

fields.name: session_variables.lower_case_file_system
fields.description: This variable describes the case sensitivity of file names on the file system where the data directory is located. OFF means file names are case sensitive, ON means they are not case sensitive. This variable is read only because it reflects a file system attribute and setting it would have no effect on the file system.

fields.name: session_variables.lower_case_table_names
fields.description: If set to 0, table names are stored as specified and comparisons are case sensitive. If set to 1, table names are stored in lowercase on disk and comparisons are not case sensitive. If set to 2, table names are stored as given but compared in lowercase. This option also applies to database names and table aliases. For additional information, see Section 9.2.2, “Identifier Case Sensitivity”.

fields.name: session_variables.master_info_repository
fields.description: The setting of this variable determines whether the slave logs master status and connection information to a FILE (master.info), or to a TABLE (mysql.slave_master_info).

fields.name: session_variables.master_verify_checksum
fields.description: Enabling this variable causes the master to examine checksums when reading from the binary log. master_verify_checksum is disabled by default; in this case, the master uses the event length from the binary log to verify events, so that only complete events are read from the binary log.

fields.name: session_variables.max_allowed_packet
fields.description: The maximum size of one packet or any generated/intermediate string, or any parameter sent by the mysql_stmt_send_long_data() C API function. The default is 4MB.

fields.name: session_variables.max_binlog_cache_size
fields.description: If a transaction requires more than this many bytes of memory, the server generates a Multi-statement transaction required more than 'max_binlog_cache_size' bytes of storage error. The minimum value is 4096. The maximum possible value is 16EB (exabytes). The maximum recommended value is 4GB; this is due to the fact that MySQL currently cannot work with binary log positions greater than 4GB.

fields.name: session_variables.max_binlog_size
fields.description: If a write to the binary log causes the current log file size to exceed the value of this variable, the server rotates the binary logs (closes the current file and opens the next one). The minimum value is 4096 bytes. The maximum and default value is 1GB.

fields.name: session_variables.max_binlog_stmt_cache_size
fields.description: If nontransactional statements within a transaction require more than this many bytes of memory, the server generates an error. The minimum value is 4096. The maximum and default values are 4GB on 32-bit platforms and 16EB (exabytes) on 64-bit platforms.

fields.name: session_variables.max_connect_errors
fields.description: If more than this many successive connection requests from a host are interrupted without a successful connection, the server blocks that host from further connections. You can unblock blocked hosts by flushing the host cache. To do so, issue a FLUSH HOSTS statement or execute a mysqladmin flush-hosts command. If a connection is established successfully within fewer than max_connect_errors attempts after a previous connection was interrupted, the error count for the host is cleared to zero. However, once a host is blocked, flushing the host cache is the only way to unblock it. The default is 100.

fields.name: session_variables.max_connections
fields.description: The maximum permitted number of simultaneous client connections. By default, this is 625. See Section B.5.2.7, “Too many connections”, for more information.

fields.name: session_variables.max_delayed_threads
fields.description: Do not start more than this number of threads to handle INSERT DELAYED statements for nontransactional tables. If you try to insert data into a new table after all INSERT DELAYED threads are in use, the row is inserted as if the DELAYED attribute was not specified. If you set this to 0, MySQL never creates a thread to handle DELAYED rows; in effect, this disables DELAYED entirely.

fields.name: session_variables.max_digest_length
fields.description: The maximum number of bytes available for computing normalized statement digests. Once that amount of space is used during digest computation, truncation occurs: no further tokens from a parsed statement are collected or figure into its digest value. Statements that differ only after that many bytes of parsed tokens produce the same normalized statement digest and are considered identical if compared or if aggregated for digest statistics.

fields.name: session_variables.max_error_count
fields.description: The maximum number of error, warning, and note messages to be stored for display by the SHOW ERRORS and SHOW WARNINGS statements. This is the same as the number of condition areas in the diagnostics area, and thus the number of conditions that can be inspected by GET DIAGNOSTICS.

fields.name: session_variables.max_insert_delayed_threads
fields.description: This variable is a synonym for max_delayed_threads.

fields.name: session_variables.max_join_size
fields.description: Do not permit statements that probably need to examine more than max_join_size rows (for single-table statements) or row combinations (for multiple-table statements) or that are likely to do more than max_join_size disk seeks. By setting this value, you can catch statements where keys are not used properly and that would probably take a long time. Set it if your users tend to perform joins that lack a WHERE clause, that take a long time, or that return millions of rows.

fields.name: session_variables.max_length_for_sort_data
fields.description: The cutoff on the size of index values that determines which filesort algorithm to use. See Section 8.2.1.13, “ORDER BY Optimization”.

fields.name: session_variables.max_prepared_stmt_count
fields.description: This variable limits the total number of prepared statements in the server. (The sum of the number of prepared statements across all sessions.) It can be used in environments where there is the potential for denial-of-service attacks based on running the server out of memory by preparing huge numbers of statements. If the value is set lower than the current number of prepared statements, existing statements are not affected and can be used, but no new statements can be prepared until the current number drops below the limit. The default value is 16,382. The permissible range of values is from 0 to 1 million. Setting the value to 0 disables prepared statements.

fields.name: session_variables.max_relay_log_size
fields.description: If a write by a replication slave to its relay log causes the current log file size to exceed the value of this variable, the slave rotates the relay logs (closes the current file and opens the next one). If max_relay_log_size is 0, the server uses max_binlog_size for both the binary log and the relay log. If max_relay_log_size is greater than 0, it constrains the size of the relay log, which enables you to have different sizes for the two logs. You must set max_relay_log_size to between 4096 bytes and 1GB (inclusive), or to 0. The default value is 0. See Section 17.2.1, “Replication Implementation Details”.

fields.name: session_variables.max_seeks_for_key
fields.description: Limit the assumed maximum number of seeks when looking up rows based on a key. The MySQL optimizer assumes that no more than this number of key seeks are required when searching for matching rows in a table by scanning an index, regardless of the actual cardinality of the index (see Section 13.7.5.23, “SHOW INDEX Syntax”). By setting this to a low value (say, 100), you can force MySQL to prefer indexes instead of table scans.

fields.name: session_variables.max_sort_length
fields.description: The number of bytes to use when sorting data values. The server uses only the first max_sort_length bytes of each value and ignores the rest. Consequently, values that differ only after the first max_sort_length bytes compare as equal for GROUP BY, ORDER BY, and DISTINCT operations.

fields.name: session_variables.max_sp_recursion_depth
fields.description: The number of times that any given stored procedure may be called recursively. The default value for this option is 0, which completely disables recursion in stored procedures. The maximum value is 255.

fields.name: session_variables.max_tmp_tables
fields.description: This variable is unused. It is deprecated and will be removed in a future MySQL release.

fields.name: session_variables.max_user_connections
fields.description: The maximum number of simultaneous connections permitted to any given MySQL user account. A value of 0 (the default) means “no limit.”

fields.name: session_variables.max_write_lock_count
fields.description: After this many write locks, permit some pending read lock requests to be processed in between.

fields.name: session_variables.metadata_locks_cache_size
fields.description: The size of the metadata locks cache. The server uses this cache to avoid creation and destruction of synchronization objects. This is particularly helpful on systems where such operations are expensive, such as Windows XP.

fields.name: session_variables.metadata_locks_hash_instances
fields.description: The set of metadata locks can be partitioned into separate hashes to permit connections accessing different objects to use different locking hashes and reduce contention. The metadata_locks_hash_instances system variable specifies the number of hashes (default 8).

fields.name: session_variables.min_examined_row_limit
fields.description: Queries that examine fewer than this number of rows are not logged to the slow query log.

fields.name: session_variables.multi_range_count
fields.description: This variable has no effect. It is deprecated and will be removed in a future MySQL release.

fields.name: session_variables.net_buffer_length
fields.description: Each client thread is associated with a connection buffer and result buffer. Both begin with a size given by net_buffer_length but are dynamically enlarged up to max_allowed_packet bytes as needed. The result buffer shrinks to net_buffer_length after each SQL statement.

fields.name: session_variables.net_read_timeout
fields.description: The number of seconds to wait for more data from a connection before aborting the read. When the server is reading from the client, net_read_timeout is the timeout value controlling when to abort. When the server is writing to the client, net_write_timeout is the timeout value controlling when to abort. See also slave_net_timeout.

fields.name: session_variables.net_retry_count
fields.description: If a read or write on a communication port is interrupted, retry this many times before giving up. This value should be set quite high on FreeBSD because internal interrupts are sent to all threads.

fields.name: session_variables.net_write_timeout
fields.description: The number of seconds to wait for a block to be written to a connection before aborting the write. See also net_read_timeout.

fields.name: session_variables.new
fields.description: This variable was used in MySQL 4.0 to turn on some 4.1 behaviors, and is retained for backward compatibility. Its value is always OFF.

fields.name: session_variables.old
fields.description: old is a compatibility variable. It is disabled by default, but can be enabled at startup to revert the server to behaviors present in older versions.

fields.name: session_variables.old_alter_table
fields.description: When this variable is enabled, the server does not use the optimized method of processing an ALTER TABLE operation. It reverts to using a temporary table, copying over the data, and then renaming the temporary table to the original, as used by MySQL 5.0 and earlier. For more information on the operation of ALTER TABLE, see Section 13.1.7, “ALTER TABLE Syntax”.

fields.name: session_variables.old_passwords
fields.description: This variable controls the password hashing method used by the PASSWORD() function. It also influences password hashing performed by CREATE USER and GRANT statements that specify a password using an IDENTIFIED BY clause.

fields.name: session_variables.open_files_limit
fields.description: The number of files that the operating system permits mysqld to open. The value of this variable at runtime is the real value permitted by the system and might be different from the value you specify at server startup. The value is 0 on systems where MySQL cannot change the number of open files.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_prune_level
fields.description: Controls the heuristics applied during query optimization to prune less-promising partial plans from the optimizer search space. A value of 0 disables heuristics so that the optimizer performs an exhaustive search. A value of 1 causes the optimizer to prune plans based on the number of rows retrieved by intermediate plans.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_search_depth
fields.description: The maximum depth of search performed by the query optimizer. Values larger than the number of relations in a query result in better query plans, but take longer to generate an execution plan for a query. Values smaller than the number of relations in a query return an execution plan quicker, but the resulting plan may be far from being optimal. If set to 0, the system automatically picks a reasonable value.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_switch
fields.description: The optimizer_switch system variable enables control over optimizer behavior. The value of this variable is a set of flags, each of which has a value of on or off to indicate whether the corresponding optimizer behavior is enabled or disabled. This variable has global and session values and can be changed at runtime. The global default can be set at server startup.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_trace
fields.description: This variable controls optimizer tracing. For details, see MySQL Internals: Tracing the Optimizer.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_trace_features
fields.description: This variable enables or disables selected optimizer tracing features. For details, see MySQL Internals: Tracing the Optimizer.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_trace_limit
fields.description: The maximum number of optimizer traces to display. For details, see MySQL Internals: Tracing the Optimizer.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_trace_max_mem_size
fields.description: The maximum cumulative size of stored optimizer traces. For details, see MySQL Internals: Tracing the Optimizer.

fields.name: session_variables.optimizer_trace_offset
fields.description: The offset of optimizer traces to display. For details, see MySQL Internals: Tracing the Optimizer.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema
fields.description: The value of this variable is ON or OFF to indicate whether the Performance Schema is enabled.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_az_digest_exclude_user
fields.description: Only for internal use. The user whose statements will not be summarized in table az_events_statements_summary_by_digest.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_az_digests_size
fields.description: The maximum number of rows in the az_events_statements_summary_by_digest table. If this maximum is exceeded such that a digest cannot be instrumented, the Performance Schema increments the Performance_schema_az_digest_lost status variable.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_az_max_sql_text_length
fields.description: The maximum number of bytes used to store SQL statements in the QUERY_SAMPLE_TEXT column of the az_events_statements_summary_by_digest event.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_consumer_az_statements_digest
fields.description: Store digest info into table az_events_statements_summary_by_digest or not.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_expand_query_sample
fields.description: Expand prepared statements or store user variables used in the query to table az_events_statements_summary_by_digest.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_cond_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of condition instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_digest_sample_age
fields.description: This variable affects statement sampling for the az_events_statements_summary_by_digest table.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_file_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of file instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_file_handles
fields.description: The maximum number of opened file objects.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_memory_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of memory instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_mutex_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of mutex instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_rwlock_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of rwlock instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_socket_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of socket instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_sql_text_length
fields.description: The maximum number of bytes used to store SQL statements in the SQL_TEXT column

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_stage_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of stage instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_statement_stack
fields.description: The maximum depth of nested stored program calls for which the Performance Schema maintains statistics.

fields.name: session_variables.performance_schema_max_thread_classes
fields.description: The maximum number of thread instruments.

fields.name: session_variables.pid_file
fields.description: The path name of the process ID (PID) file. On Windows, this variable also affects the default error log file name. See Section 5.4.2, “The Error Log”. This variable can be set with the --pid-file option.

fields.name: session_variables.plugin_dir
fields.description: The path name of the plugin directory.

fields.name: session_variables.port
fields.description: The number of the port on which the server listens for TCP/IP connections. This variable can be set with the --port option.

fields.name: session_variables.preload_buffer_size
fields.description: The size of the buffer that is allocated when preloading indexes.

fields.name: session_variables.profiling
fields.description: If set to 0 or OFF (the default), statement profiling is disabled. If set to 1 or ON, statement profiling is enabled and the SHOW PROFILE and SHOW PROFILES statements provide access to profiling information. This variable is deprecated and will be removed in a future MySQL release.

fields.name: session_variables.profiling_history_size
